title: Pair of Side Chairs

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of mahogany, ash, birch, and upholstery.

artist_display:
Carving attributed to Samuel McIntire
American, 1757–1811
Salem, Massachusetts
description: The design of these chairs was taken almost directly from plate two of Englishman George Hepplewhite’s 1788 edition of The Cabinetmaker and Upholsterer’s Guide, a pattern book that was available in America. The two chairs are part of a set of eight that may have originally been made for Salem merchant Elias Hasket Derby. The house for which these chairs were made was designed by Samuel McIntire, the craftsman to whom the carving on the chairs is attributed.
credit_line: Purchased with funds provided by the Antiquarian Society through the Edith Almy Adams Fund

Art Institute of Chicago, Antiquarian Society of The Art Institute of Chicago, The First One Hundred Years, Apr. 23–June 19, 1977, cat. 144.
provenance_text: Probably Elias Haskett Derby (1739–1799), Salem, MA, by 1799; probably estate of Elias Haskett Derby, 1799; by descent to his son-in-law Captain Nathaniel West Sr. (1756–1851) and daughter Elizabeth Derby West (1762–1814), Salem and Danvers (now Peabody), MA, 1799 [Nathaniel and Elizabeth divorced in 1806, at which time the McIntire chairs either stayed with Elizabeth at Oak Hill in Danvers or went with Nathaniel to 34 Chestnut Street or 5–9 Summer Street (built 1834), both in Salem]. Possibly bequeathed by Elizabeth to her three daughters Martha Derby West (1787–1851), Elizabeth (Eliza) West Lander (1790–1849), and Sarah Derby West (1797–1819), 1814 [upon Sarah’s death in 1814, Nathaniel West Sr. regained 1/3 ownership of Oak Hill and its contents, and upon Elizabeth West Lander’s death in 1849, her share passed by descent to her husband Edward Lander (1787–1862), who then transferred his share of Oak Hill to his father-in-law Nathaniel West Sr. in 1849; West sold Oak Hill in 1850 and would have transferred its remaining contents at that time to one of his 5–9 Summer Street townhouses in Salem]. By descent to Nathaniel West Sr.’s son Richard West (died 1879); by descent to his son William C. West (1844–1928), Boston, 1879; by descent to his wife, Abbie C. Farley West (died 1932), Boston, 1928; estate of Abbie C. Farley West, Boston, 1932; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1938.
